case_name: Shree Ram Mills Limited v. Excess Profits Tax Officer

facts.text: This appeal comes from Bombay

anchor.surface_text: This appeal companyes from Bombay.

facts.text: The assessee is the Shree Ram Mills Limited of Bombay

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is the Shree Ram Mills Limited of Bombay.

facts.text: The assessment year is 1945-46

anchor.surface_text: and the accounting year is the calendar year 1944.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer assessed the profits for income-tax at Rs. 46,18,384

facts.text: The Excess Profits Tax Officer computed the profits for excess profits tax purposes at Rs. 46,94,304

anchor.surface_text: The Excess Profits Tax Officer companyputed the profits, for excess profits tax purposes, at Rs. 46,94,304.

facts.text: The Excess Profits Tax Officer excluded certain items like money given away as presents and in charity in determining how the profits increased the capital

anchor.surface_text: Rule No. 5 in Schedule II. issues.text: Whether on a true construction of Rule 5 of Schedule II of the Excess Profits Tax Act the expression so far as the contrary is shown applies only to sub-clause a or also to sub-clause b?

anchor.surface_text: The High Court resettled the first question we are asked to answer as follows - Whether on a true companystruction of Rule 5 of Schedule II of the Excess Profits Tax Act the expression so far as the companytrary is shown applies only to sub-clause  a  or also to sub-clause  b  ?

issues.text: Whether the managing agency commission payable by the company to its managing agents for the year 1943 is borrowed money for the purposes of Rule 2A or a debt for the purposes of Rule 2 of Schedule II to the Excess Profits Tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the managing agency companymission payable by the companypany to its managing agents for the year 1943 is borrowed money for the purposes of Rule 2A or a debt for the purposes of Rule 2 of Schedule II to the Excess Profits Tax Act ?

arguments.claim: The words 'except so far as the contrary is shown' only govern clause (a) and not clause (b)

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the assessee contends that the words only govern clause  a  and not clause  b .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nly govern clause  a  and number clause  b . His companytention is that Rule 5 is an artificial rule which creates a fiction, namely that the profits

arguments.court_reasoning: The word 'deemed' clearly governs both clauses, and the words 'except so far as the contrary is shown' govern both clauses allowing independent rebuttal

arguments.claim: Since the department accepted that profits accrued at an even rate under clause (a), the department is bound to apply clause (b)

anchor.surface_text: The department has accepted in this case that the profits accrued at an even rate because the assessee has not rebutted that presumption nor has the department attempted to do so. The learned counsel for the assessee contends that that being so, the department is bound to apply clause  b

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nly govern clause  a  and number clause  b . His companytention is that Rule 5 is an artificial rule which creates a fiction, namely that the profits

arguments.court_reasoning: Each presumption in clauses (a) and (b) can be rebutted independently; rebuttal of one does not affect the other

arguments.claim: Rule 5 creates a single fiction of even accrual such that clause (b) is a mere corollary to clause (a) with no independent existence

anchor.surface_text: His contention is that Rule 5 is an artificial rule which creates a fiction, namely that the profits accrue evenly over the year even when that is not the fact. Therefore the moment either party shows that this is not the case Rule 5 falls to the ground as a whole because the artificial presumption it created has been rebutted. Clause  b , he contends, cannot have any independent existence because it is a mere corollary to clause  a .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nly govern clause  a  and number clause  b . His companytention is that Rule 5 is an artificial rule which creates a fiction, namely that the profits

arguments.court_reasoning: The Rule creates two fictions: even accrual and corresponding capital change; each governed by 'deemed' and rebuttable separately by 'except so far as the contrary is shown'

arguments.claim: The expression 'except so far as the contrary is shown' applies to both clauses (a) and (b) of Rule 5

anchor.surface_text: We do not agree. The word deemed clearly governs both clauses, for the fiction which the Rule creates is not only that the profits shall be deemed to have accrued at an even rate throughout the period, but further that they must be deemed to have resulted, as they accrued,

arguments.claim: The managing agency commission is a debt within the meaning of Rule 2

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax says it is a debt within the meaning of Rule 2.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n on the part of the managing agents cannot companyvert the money due to them, and number withdrawn,

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees with High Court that it is a debt under Rule 2

arguments.claim: The clause in the Articles of Agreement converts the commission into a loan by agreement

anchor.surface_text: The clause in the Articles of Agreement quoted above was relied on for the purpose of showing that there was such an agreement in the case.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he Commissioner of Income-tax says it is a debt within the meaning of Rule 2. We agree with the High Court that this is a debt and number a borrowing.

arguments.court_reasoning: Unable to construe the provisions that way; they merely give the managing agents a right to receive their commission at a certain time; if not paid, it lies as a debt

arguments.claim: A loan requires a positive act of lending coupled with acceptance; mere inaction does not create borrower-lender relationship

anchor.surface_text: A loan imports a positive act of lending coupled with an acceptance by the other side of the money as a loan. The relationship of borrower and lender cannot ordinarily come about by mere inaction.

holdings.text: The expression 'so far as the contrary is shown' in Rule 5 of Schedule II applies to both sub-clauses (a) and (b)

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the answer given by the High Court, namely that the words so far as the companytrary is shown apply to both clauses  a  and  b .

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Deemed' governs both clauses creating separate fictions of even accrual and capital impact; exception phrase applies to both allowing independent rebuttal of each presumption

holdings.text: The managing agency commission left with the assessee is a debt under Rule 2 of Schedule II and not a borrowing under Rule 2A

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that it is a debt under Rule 2 and number a borrowing under Rule 2A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requires positive act of lending and acceptance to constitute borrowing; mere inaction or failure to withdraw debt does not convert it into loan; agreement clause merely fixes payment time

holdings.text: The presumptions in clauses (a) and (b) of Rule 5 are independent and rebuttal of one does not affect the other

anchor.surface_text: Thus, it can be shown either that the profits did number accrue at an even rate throughout the period or that the profits did number actually go to increase the capital, as for example when it was taken out of the business and handed over to charities and so forth, and if only one of the two presumptions is rebutted, the other stands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule creates two distinct artificial presumptions, each rebuttable separately by showing contrary facts

holdings.text: A loan/borrowing requires a positive act of lending coupled with acceptance; relationship of borrower and lender cannot ordinarily come about by mere inaction

anchor.surface_text: A loan imports a positive act of lending companypled with an acceptance by the other side of the money as a loan. The relationship of borrower and lender cannot ordinarily companye about by mere inaction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes debt from borrowing based on active transaction, not passive retention of due amount

Rule 2 of Schedule II to Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940 support defeaters

anchor.surface_text: The High Court resettled the first question we are asked to answer as follows - Whether on a true companystruction of Rule 5 of Schedule II of the Excess Profits Tax Act the expression so far as the companytrary is shown applies only to sub-clause  a  or also to sub-clause  b  ? We agree with the answer given by the High Court, namely that the words so far as the companytrary is shown apply to both clauses  a  and  b . The next question is about the managing agency companymission. Under the Articles of Agreement entered into between the assessee and its managing agents the agents were to be paid a certain companymission and the articles provided - The said companymission shall be due to the said firm yearly on the thirty-first day of December in each and every year during the companytinuance of this agreement and shall be payable and be paid immediately after annual accounts of the said companypany have been passed by the shareholders of the companypany The managing agents left the companymission lying with the assessee. The assessee companytends that this companystitutes a borrowing within the meaning of Rule 2A of Schedule II. The Commissioner of Income-tax says it is a debt within the meaning of Rule 2. We agree with the High Court that this is a debt and number a borrowing.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court decision upheld on both issues: 'so far as the contrary is shown' applies to both clauses (a) and (b) of Rule 5; managing agency commission is a debt under Rule 2, not borrowed money under Rule 2A.
